title: Classic Spaghetti Carbonara
description: A traditional Roman pasta dish with eggs, cheese, pancetta, and black pepper.
instructions: Boil water for pasta.
Fry pancetta until crispy.
Whisk eggs and cheese.
Cook pasta al dente.
Mix everything off heat to create sauce.

title: Avocado Toast
description: Simple, healthy, and delicious breakfast staple.
instructions: Toast the bread.
Mash avocado with lemon, salt, and pepper.
Spread on toast.
Sprinkle with chili flakes.

_comment: Nigerian-based recipes start here – all authentic dishes from Nigeria, contributed by Salma's Nigerian Kitchen
title: Authentic Nigerian Jollof Rice
description: The iconic West African one-pot rice dish cooked in a rich, spicy tomato-pepper base. Smoky, flavorful, and a staple at Nigerian parties and gatherings.
ingredients: 3 cups long-grain parboiled rice (or basmati for a premium version)
1/2 cup vegetable oil or palm oil
Protein of choice (chicken, beef, or fish – optional)
instructions: Blend peppers, tomatoes, onions, and scotch bonnet into a smooth puree.
Heat oil in a pot, fry sliced onion until translucent, then add tomato paste and fry for 5-10 minutes until it darkens.
Add the blended puree, stock cubes, thyme, curry, bay leaves, and salt. Cook on medium heat until the oil floats on top (about 15-20 mins).
Parboil rice if needed, then add to the stew. Stir gently, add water/stock to just cover the rice.
Cover and cook on low heat until rice is tender and fluffy (20-30 mins). Avoid stirring too much to prevent sogginess. Add protein midway if using.
Serve hot with fried plantains (dodo) or coleslaw.

title: Egusi Soup
description: A rich, nutty melon seed soup popular across Nigeria, often thickened and paired with swallows like pounded yam or eba. Packed with protein and greens.
ingredients: Assorted meats (beef, goat, tripe, or smoked fish – about 1-2 lbs)
2-3 cups chopped spinach or ugu/pumpkin leaves
Locust beans (iru, optional for extra flavor)
instructions: Season and boil meats until tender, reserve stock.
Blend peppers and one onion, then mix ground egusi with a little water to form a thick paste.
Heat palm oil, sauté chopped onion, add blended peppers and fry for 10 minutes.
Add crayfish, locust beans, stock cubes, and meat stock. Simmer.
Scoop egusi paste into the pot in lumps (or stir in for smoother texture). Cook 10-15 mins without stirring much to form lumps.
Add chopped greens and cooked meats. Simmer 5-10 more minutes. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with pounded yam, eba, or fufu.

title: Pounded Yam (Iyan)
description: A classic swallow made from boiled yam, pounded into a smooth, stretchy dough. Perfect partner for egusi, okro, or other Nigerian soups.
ingredients: 1 medium tuber of yam (white yam, not sweet potato yam)
instructions: Peel yam, cut into chunks, and wash thoroughly.
Boil in salted water until very soft (15-20 mins).
Drain, then pound in a mortar and pestle (traditional) or use a food processor/stand mixer until smooth and stretchy. Add small amounts of hot water if too stiff.
Mold into a smooth ball and serve hot with soup.

title: Nigerian Beef Suya
description: Spicy grilled meat skewers coated in a peanut-based yaji spice mix – a iconic Nigerian street food snack, perfect for evenings or parties.
ingredients: 1/4 cup ground roasted peanuts (or peanut powder)
2-3 tbsp suya spice (yaji – mix of ground peanuts, ginger, garlic, cayenne, paprika)
Sliced onions, tomatoes, and cucumber for serving
instructions: Slice beef thinly against the grain.
Mix suya spice, ground peanuts, ginger, garlic, cayenne, stock cube, and salt.
Rub the spice mix generously over the beef slices. Marinate for at least 1 hour (or overnight).
Thread meat onto skewers.
Grill over high heat (or broil in oven) for 10-15 minutes, turning and brushing with oil until charred and cooked.
Serve hot with extra suya spice, sliced onions, tomatoes, and cucumber.

title: Puff Puff
description: Crispy, fluffy deep-fried dough balls – a sweet Nigerian street snack or party finger food, often enjoyed with a cold drink.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, salt, nutmeg, and yeast in a bowl.
Gradually add warm water and mix to form a thick, smooth batter (like pancake batter).
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1-2 hours until doubled and bubbly.
Heat oil to medium-hot (test with a drop – it should sizzle).
Scoop batter with wet hands or spoon and drop into oil in small balls.
Fry until golden brown, turning for even cooking (about 3-5 mins). Drain on paper towels.
Optional: Roll in sugar while hot. Serve warm.

title: Okra Soup (Okro Soup)
description: A slimy, flavorful soup made with fresh okra, often combined with meats or fish – a go-to comfort dish served with swallows like eba or pounded yam.
ingredients: 500g fresh okra (chopped or blended for sliminess)
Assorted meats/fish (beef, goat, stockfish, or dried fish – about 500g)
instructions: Boil meats/fish with onion, stock cubes, and salt until tender; reserve stock.
Heat palm oil, sauté onion and blended pepper for 5-10 mins.
Add crayfish, locust beans, and some stock; simmer.
Stir in chopped/blended okra (don't overcook to keep draw). Cook 5-8 mins on low.
Add cooked meats/fish and greens. Simmer 5 more mins. Adjust seasoning.
Serve hot with fufu, eba, or pounded yam.

title: Nigerian Pepper Soup
description: A hot, spicy, aromatic broth with meat or fish – great as a starter, remedy for colds, or evening warmer.
ingredients: 1 kg assorted meat (goat, chicken, or fish)
Pepper soup spice mix (or make with ehuru, uziza, uda, calabash nutmeg)
Fresh scent leaves or uziza leaves (optional)
instructions: Season meat with onion, stock cubes, and salt; boil until half-cooked.
Add blended pepper, spice mix, and more water/stock to cover.
Simmer until meat is tender and broth is flavorful (30-45 mins).
Add chopped leaves in the last 5 mins. Adjust seasoning (should be very spicy).
Serve hot in bowls, often with chilled drink.

title: Moi Moi (Moin Moin)
description: Steamed bean pudding – a protein-packed side dish, often served with jollof rice, pap, or as a snack.
ingredients: 2 cups peeled beans (black-eyed or brown beans)
instructions: Blend soaked/peeled beans with peppers, onion, and some water to a smooth paste.
Mix in oil, stock cubes, salt, and any add-ins.
Whip or beat for fluffiness (traditional method).
Pour into greased molds, ramekins, or wrapped leaves; add egg/fish if using.
Steam for 30-45 mins until set and firm.
Cool slightly, unmold, and serve warm or cold.

title: Akara (Bean Cakes)
description: Crispy, fluffy deep-fried bean fritters – a beloved Nigerian breakfast or snack, often paired with pap (ogi) or eaten on the go.
instructions: Soak peeled beans for a few hours if needed, then blend with peppers, half the onion, and minimal water to a thick, smooth paste.
Add salt and beat/whip the batter vigorously for 5-10 minutes (traditional method) until light and fluffy.
Heat oil to medium-hot.
Scoop batter with wet spoon or hands and drop into oil to form small rounds.
Fry until golden brown on both sides (flip once), about 3-5 minutes.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.

title: Efo Riro (Vegetable Stew)
description: Rich, spicy Yoruba-style stew loaded with assorted meats, fish, and leafy greens like spinach or ugu – a flavorful everyday soup.
ingredients: 500g assorted meats/fish (beef, tripe, ponmo, smoked fish)
4-5 red bell peppers + 2 scotch bonnet peppers (blended)
instructions: Boil meats/fish with seasoning until tender; reserve stock.
Heat palm oil, fry chopped onion, add tomato paste and fry 5-10 mins.
Add blended peppers, crayfish, iru, stock cubes; cook until oil separates.
Add cooked meats/fish and some stock; simmer 10 mins.
Stir in chopped greens, cook 5-7 mins (don't overcook greens). Adjust seasoning.
Serve with rice, yam, plantain, or swallow.

title: Afang Soup
description: Thick, nutritious Efik soup made with wild vegetable leaves (afang), water leaves, and palm oil base – a Cross River classic full of flavor.
instructions: Boil meats/stockfish/periwinkles with seasoning until tender.
Blend peppers and onion; heat palm oil, sauté blended mix briefly.
Add crayfish, stock cubes, and meat stock; simmer.
Add chopped water leaves/spinach first, cook 5 mins.
Stir in shredded afang leaves (don't over-stir to keep texture). Simmer 5-10 mins.
Add cooked meats. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with pounded yam, fufu, or garri.

title: Banga Soup (Ofe Akwu)
description: Rich, nutty palm nut soup from the Niger Delta – aromatic with spices, perfect with starch, pounded yam, or rice.
ingredients: 1 kg palm fruit extract (or banga puree)
Assorted meats/fish (beef, dry fish, fresh catfish – about 1 kg)
1-2 tbsp Banga spice (or make with atama, oburunbebe stick, etc.)
Dried bitter leaf (optional for Delta version)
instructions: Extract palm nut juice or use ready puree; boil meats/fish until tender.
Cook palm nut extract until it thickens and oil rises.
Add blended pepper, onion, Banga spice, stock cubes; simmer.
Add cooked meats, periwinkles, and bitter leaf if using.
Cook on low until flavors meld (20-30 mins). Adjust seasoning.
Serve hot with starch swallow or white rice.

title: Chin Chin
description: Crunchy, sweet fried dough snack – a Nigerian party staple, great for gifting or munching anytime.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, baking powder, nutmeg.
Rub in margarine until crumbly.
Add beaten eggs and milk/water; knead into firm dough.
Roll out dough thinly, cut into small strips or squares.
Heat oil to medium, fry in batches until golden and crunchy (stir to avoid sticking).
Drain on paper towels. Optional: toss in extra sugar while hot.
Store in airtight container.

title: Yam Porridge (Asaro)
description: A hearty, one-pot yam dish cooked in a spicy palm oil-based pepper sauce – comforting and filling, popular across Nigeria especially in Yoruba homes.
ingredients: 1 medium tuber puna yam (peeled and cut into chunks)
2-3 red bell peppers + 2 scotch bonnet peppers (blended)
Assorted proteins (beef, dry fish, or smoked fish – optional)
Ugu or spinach leaves (chopped, optional for greens version)
instructions: Blend peppers and one onion into a puree.
Heat palm oil, sauté chopped onion until translucent.
Add blended peppers, stock cubes, salt; fry until oil separates (10-15 mins).
Add yam chunks and enough water to cover; cook until yam is soft and porridge thickens (20-30 mins). Mash some yam for creaminess.
Add proteins and greens in the last 5-10 mins. Adjust seasoning.
Serve hot as a main dish.

title: Ofada Rice with Ayamase Sauce
description: Unpolished local rice served with a rich, spicy green pepper stew (Ayamase) – a Lagos/Southwest delicacy with bold, fermented flavors.
ingredients: 2 cups ofada rice (or local unpolished rice)
instructions: Boil meats until tender; reserve stock.
Heat palm oil until it smokes slightly (bleached oil method), add iru and blended peppers/onion; fry carefully to avoid burning.
Add cooked meats, stock cubes, salt; simmer until sauce thickens and oil floats.
Cook ofada rice separately (parboil if needed, then boil until soft).
Serve rice topped with Ayamase sauce and boiled eggs if desired.

title: Ogbono Soup
description: Drawy, nutty soup made from ground ogbono seeds – thick and hearty, a favorite swallow companion in many Nigerian homes.
instructions: Boil meats/fish with seasoning until tender; reserve stock.
Heat palm oil, sauté chopped onion and blended pepper briefly.
Add crayfish, stock cubes, meat stock; bring to simmer.
Mix ogbono with a little water/oil to form paste, scoop into soup in lumps; cook 10-15 mins without much stirring to draw.
Add greens and meats; simmer 5 mins. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with fufu, eba, or pounded yam.

title: Edikaikong Soup
description: Nutritious Calabar vegetable soup loaded with ugu and water leaves – rich in vitamins, often with assorted seafood and meats.
ingredients: Equal parts ugu (pumpkin) and water leaves (or spinach substitute, chopped finely)
Assorted meats/fish (beef, dry fish, periwinkle, prawns)
instructions: Boil meats/fish/periwinkles until tender.
Heat palm oil, sauté blended pepper and onion.
Add crayfish, stock cubes, meat stock; simmer.
Add water leaves first, cook 5 mins; then ugu leaves, simmer 5-10 mins (don't overcook to keep vibrant green).
Add cooked meats/seafood. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with pounded yam or fufu.

title: Nigerian Fried Rice
description: Colorful, flavorful rice stir-fried with veggies, proteins, and spices – a party and everyday favorite.
ingredients: Mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, green beans, sweet corn)
instructions: Season and cook proteins; chop into bits.
Heat oil, sauté onion, add veggies and stir-fry 5 mins.
Add proteins, spices, stock cubes; mix well.
Add cooled rice gradually, stir-fry on high heat to avoid sogginess (5-10 mins).
Serve hot with fried plantain or coleslaw.

title: Fried Plantain (Dodo)
description: Sweet, caramelized ripe plantain slices fried to golden perfection – a classic side for rice, stew, or beans.
instructions: Peel and slice plantains diagonally or round.
Heat oil to medium-hot.
Fry in batches until golden brown on both sides (flip once).
Drain on paper towels. Sprinkle salt if desired.
Serve warm as a side or snack.

title: Ewedu Soup (Jute Leaves Soup)
description: Light, drawy green soup from jute leaves – Yoruba classic, often paired with stew and swallow.
ingredients: 1/2 cup palm oil or vegetable oil
instructions: Pick and wash ewedu leaves thoroughly.
Boil meats if using; reserve stock.
Blend or pound ewedu lightly (traditional) or chop finely.
Boil water/stock with crayfish, iru, stock cubes; add ewedu, cook 5-8 mins on low (don't overcook).
Add oil and meats. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with amala, eba, or stew.

title: Masa (Rice Cakes)
description: Soft, spongy fermented rice pancakes – Northern Nigerian breakfast/snack, often with spicy stew or soup.
ingredients: 2 cups tuwo rice or short-grain rice (soaked overnight)
instructions: Soak rice overnight, drain, blend with minimal water to thick batter.
Add yeast, sugar, salt; ferment 6-12 hours until bubbly.
Stir in baking powder.
Heat masa pan (or non-stick with wells), oil lightly, pour batter into holes.
Cook until bubbles form and bottom browns; flip if needed.
Serve hot with pepper soup, stew, or honey.

title: Tuwon Shinkafa (Rice Swallow)
description: Soft, smooth swallow made from cooked rice – Northern favorite, pairs well with soups like miyan kuka or ogbono.
instructions: Wash rice, boil in water until very soft and mushy (extra water).
Mash/pound with wooden spoon or blender until smooth and stretchy.
Mold into balls or serve in lumps.
Serve hot with any soup.

title: White Rice & Stew
description: Simple boiled white rice with rich tomato-pepper stew – everyday comfort food, versatile with proteins and sides.
ingredients: For stew: 4-5 tomatoes + peppers + onions (blended), 1/2 cup palm/veg oil, tomato paste, stock cubes, assorted meats/fish
instructions: Cook rice in salted water until tender; set aside.
Fry tomato paste in oil, add blended puree, spices; cook until oil floats.
Add cooked meats/fish, simmer.
Serve stew over rice with dodo or salad.

_comment: Nigerian desserts start here – sweet treats and snacks popular in Nigeria, contributed by Salma's Nigerian Kitchen
title: Nigerian Coconut Candy (Kuli Kuli Sweet Variation)
description: Crunchy, chewy coconut candy made with fresh coconut and sugar – a simple, traditional sweet snack enjoyed across Nigeria.
instructions: Mix grated coconut and sugar in a pan over medium heat.
Stir continuously until sugar melts and mixture thickens (about 10-15 mins).
Add ginger and salt; cook until it starts to pull away from the pan.
Pour onto greased surface, cool slightly, cut into pieces.
Let harden and store in airtight container.

title: Shuku Shuku (Coconut Cookies)
description: Crispy, buttery coconut balls – a classic Nigerian treat often served at parties or as an after-meal sweet.
instructions: Cream butter and sugar until fluffy.
Beat in eggs and vanilla.
Mix in flour, baking powder, and coconut to form dough.
Roll into small balls; bake at 180°C for 15-20 mins until golden.
Cool and serve.

title: Plantain Chips (Crunchy Sweet Version)
description: Thin, crispy fried plantain slices lightly sweetened – a popular snack/dessert alternative to savory chips.
instructions: Peel and slice plantains thinly.
Fry in hot oil until golden and crisp.
Drain on paper towels; dust with sugar and cinnamon while hot.
Serve as a sweet crunchy treat.

title: Nigerian Pancakes (Crepes Style)
description: Thin, sweet pancakes often enjoyed as a dessert or breakfast treat with honey or fruit.
instructions: Whisk flour, sugar, salt; add eggs, milk, vanilla to make smooth batter.
Heat butter in pan; pour small amount of batter, swirl to spread thin.
Cook 1-2 mins per side until golden.
Serve rolled with honey or jam.

title: Rock Buns (Nigerian Sweet Buns)
description: Hard, sweet drop buns with coconut or raisins – a classic bakery-style dessert/snack.
instructions: Rub margarine into flour, sugar, baking powder.
Add egg, milk, coconut/raisins; mix to stiff dough.
Drop spoonfuls on greased tray.
Bake at 180°C for 20-25 mins until golden.
Cool and enjoy.

title: Donkwa (Peanut Candy)
description: Crunchy peanut and cornmeal candy from Northern Nigeria – sweet, nutty, and addictive.
instructions: Dry-fry cornmeal until fragrant.
Boil sugar and water to soft-ball stage.
Mix in peanuts and cornmeal; stir quickly.
Pour onto greased surface, flatten, cool, and cut into pieces.

title: Alkubus/Alkaki (Sweet Wheat Fritters)
description: Yeasted wheat fritters soaked in syrup – a Northern Nigerian sweet treat.
instructions: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, water to dough; let rise 1 hour.
Form small balls; fry until golden.
Boil sugar and water to syrup; soak fritters in it.
Serve warm or cold.

title: Plantain Mosa (Sweet Plantain Puff Puff)
description: Overripe plantain mixed into puff puff batter – sweet, fluffy, and irresistible.
instructions: Mash plantains; mix with flour, sugar, yeast, water to batter.
Let rise 1-2 hours.
Scoop and fry until golden.
Dust with sugar and serve.

title: Coconut Cake (Simple Nigerian Style)
description: Moist coconut-flavored cake – a homemade favorite for celebrations.
instructions: Cream butter and sugar; add eggs one by one.
Mix in flour, baking powder, coconut, vanilla.
Bake in greased pan at 180°C for 35-40 mins.
Cool and slice.

title: Tuwon Madara (Milk Fudge)
description: Rich, condensed milk-based fudge from Northern Nigeria – very sweet and creamy.
instructions: Boil milk and sugar on low heat, stirring constantly.
Cook until thick and pulling away (30-45 mins).
Add butter and vanilla; pour into greased dish.
Cool, cut into squares.

title: Banana Fritters (Plantain Alternative)
description: Ripe bananas battered and fried – sweet, golden bites similar to puff puff.
instructions: Mash bananas; mix with flour, sugar, baking powder, little water.
Drop spoonfuls into hot oil; fry until golden.
Drain and serve warm.

title: Gulisua (Sesame Candy)
description: Crunchy sesame seed brittle – a Northern sweet snack with honey-like flavor.
instructions: Toast sesame seeds lightly.
Boil sugar and water to hard-crack stage.
Stir in seeds; pour onto greased surface.
Cool and break into pieces.

title: Nigerian Doughnuts (Bofrot Style Sweet)
description: Fluffy, yeasted doughnuts dusted with sugar – a popular street dessert.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, water to dough; let rise 1 hour.
Shape into rings or balls; fry until golden.
Dust with sugar while hot.

title: Zobo Jelly with Tigernut
description: Refreshing hibiscus (zobo) jelly layered with tigernut milk – modern Nigerian dessert twist.
instructions: Prepare zobo; dissolve gelatin in it, pour into molds, chill.
Layer with sweetened tigernut milk jelly.
Chill until set; serve cold.

title: Semolina Puff Puff (Sweet Variation)
description: Fluffy semolina-based puffs dusted with sugar – lighter alternative to flour puff puff.
instructions: Mix semolina, sugar, yeast, water to batter; rise 1-2 hours.
Fry small scoops until golden.
Dust with sugar.

title: Peanut Brittle (Egusi-Style Sweet)
description: Hard caramel with roasted peanuts – simple homemade brittle.
instructions: Boil sugar and water to amber color.
Stir in peanuts; pour onto greased tray.
Cool and break.

title: Fruit Skewers (Fresh Dessert)
description: Colorful fresh fruit on sticks with honey drizzle – light Nigerian party dessert.
instructions: Cube fruits; thread onto skewers.
Drizzle with honey.
Chill and serve.

title: Vanilla Ice Cream (Homemade Nigerian Style)
description: Creamy no-churn vanilla ice cream – popular homemade treat.
instructions: Whip cream to stiff peaks.
Fold in condensed milk and vanilla.
Freeze 6+ hours; scoop and serve.

title: Kantun Ridi (Tiger Nut Sweet)
description: Sweetened tiger nut balls or bars – Northern-inspired energy dessert.
instructions: Mix ground tiger nuts with honey to form dough.
Roll into balls or press into bars.
Coat with coconut; chill.

title: Coconut Nests (M&M Style)
description: Crispy coconut nests with colorful candies – fun party dessert.
instructions: Melt chocolate; mix with coconut.
Shape into nests on tray; add candies.
Chill until set.

title: Traditional Rice Cake (Waina)
description: A traditional Northern Nigerian dish by by Hausa people. It is fluffy, slightly tangy, round, or oval-shaped snack or meal often served with soup.
instructions: Soak the rice
Grind into a smooth paste
Add sugar, yeast, and water
Leave to ferment
Cook in a special waina pan over heat.
And then you serve with soup with kuli-kuli
